text: Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow.

text: Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? text: Family Member: And is that for all chemotherapy or just this specific one that T___ has? Doctor: The neuropathies, the eye tearing are pretty specific to this drug. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the rest of it because we’re killing dividing cells, Family Member: Uh hum. the hair loss, the drops in blood count are consistent with chemotherapy. Doctor: Yeah, we do, you know we know what we need to give you to sort of prevent the nausea when you’re getting the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. text: Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter.

text: Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly. Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now.

text: Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: He told me to start weaning off from the tamoxifen. Patient: And that stuff is nasty to get off from. Doctor: Go slow. Patient: Yeah. That’s right. So I don’t know if that’s going to effect- Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. During the- this is different than the Lupron and that right? Isn’t this usually used for gastric? Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: Radiation treatment was. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: So it wasn’t doing anything up here or the middle of the spine. Doctor: No. No. Right. And that would be true for proton. Protons are you know there’s a spot I want and- Patient: Site specific. Doctor: Very. So the question is do you color right up to the line you know with a two millimeter ballpoint pen or do you have a five millimeter ballpoint pen. So you’re trying to cut it out and draw an outline. You know? Will you get more precise? Yeah you might get more precise but is there any meaning to that for the patient. And that’s what we don’t know. So new stuff. I think we have to keep an eye on that technology to see what they think. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
